Award.AwardTitle: ASEE/NSF Small Business Postdoctoral Research Diversity Fellowship Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
The intellectual merit of this proposal is that this program allows highly educated scientists and engineers to acquire real-life research experience and to bring the latest innovative theories and techniques from the academic community o the country?s entrepreneurial technology sector. By working in a cutting-edge laboratory where research and development are accomplished within a framework of expected business outcomes and business constraints, researchers learn to work in multidisciplinary teams and to apply their academic expertise to the important work of product development and application in a globally competitive environment. The small businesses benefit from the fresh insights and most current technological skills and training that the recent postdoctoral students would bring. The program puts those skills and that training to work at creative and inventive research companies which otherwise would not be able to afford such expertise. These pairings would provide active SBIR Phase II companies the opportunity to enhance innovative collaboration, strengthen scientific rigor, and quicken the pace of technological breakthrough. Fellows are also encouraged to publish their work within the overall publishing guidelines set by each participating company.


The broader impact of this program is to broaden participation of underrepresented groups such as women, African
Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, and Hawaiian/Pacific Islanders in small high-tech companies supported by the NSF SBIR/STTR program. ASEE has proposed stronger outreach strategies than implemented in the current grant to increase visibility and diversity by reaching out to institutions that supply a high number of candidates from underrepresented demographic groups. ASEE is strengthening its outreach by attending postdoctoral and professional organizational conferences that typically target women and underrepresented groups in STEM fields and by having a proactive presence in social media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the start of the Small Business Postdoctoral Research Diversity Fellowship (SBPRDF) in 2015, 53 one-year and two-year postdoctoral fellowships were awarded to scholars to participate in innovative research at NSF Phase II SBIR companies. The SBPRDF aimed to provide postdoctoral fellows with an educational opportunity outside the traditional academic setting, allowing them to further their careers and apply their technical knowledge under business constraints. The host company received the benefit of recruiting high-value talent from the nation’s graduate schools at a fraction of the usual cost. In exchange for this benefit, companies agreed to mentor their Fellow and provide the necessary tools to address the agreed upon workplan. The SBPRDF is the sequel to a previous award of the same title, NSF # 1059286.

A 2019 survey of program fellows and mentors revealed significant results.  Eighty-five percent of Fellows reported that the fellowship gave them a competitive advantage for the type of work they will do next. Nearly 75 percent of Fellows reported that they found at least one mentor who will help them or has helped them professionally after their fellowship. All program Mentors, who responded to the survey, said they would recommend the SBPRDF program to colleagues looking to screen highly talented individuals for long­term employment.

Host companies derived value from scholars in this program. Seventy-three percent of SBPRDF fellows, who responded to the survey, were offered employment at the Host Company upon completion of their fellowship. This cohort was also the most diverse in the history of the program and this program’s predecessors. The participation of women and underrepresented minorities in the SBPRDF rose from 38% in FY15 to 65.3% in FY18.

The survey also revealed unexpected economic impacts. Close to half the Mentors surveyed reported they gave stock options to their Fellow and one third of Fellows said they were offered stock options and / or other deferred compensation when hired by their company. Fifty percent of Fellows who received stock options, reported they were able to exercise their options and participate in a liquidity event.

During their appointments, fellowship participants published technical (conference and journal) articles, gave technical and business presentations, built prototypes, designed experiments, authored patents, and won new SBIR grants. Those who were not hired by their host company were readily hired into industry, sought another postdoctoral education opportunity, or took tenure track academic positions.

Overall, we believe the SBPRDF has the potential to be a model for broadening participation in small business innovative research and entrepreneurship.
